DeepLTL: Learning to Efficiently Satisfy
Complex LTL Specifications

Mathias Jackermeier, Alessandro Abate
Department of Computer Science, University of Oxford
{mathias.jackermeier,alessandro.abate}@cs.ox.ac.uk
Abstract

Linear temporal logic (LTL) has recently been adopted as a powerful formalism for specifying complex, temporally extended tasks in reinforcement learning (RL). However, learning policies that efficiently satisfy arbitrary specifications not observed during training remains a challenging problem. Existing approaches suffer from several shortcomings: they are often only applicable to finite-horizon fragments of LTL, are restricted to suboptimal solutions, and do not adequately handle safety constraints. In this work, we propose a novel learning approach to address these concerns. Our method leverages the structure of BÃ¼chi automata, which explicitly represent the semantics of LTL specifications, to learn policies conditioned on sequences of truth assignments that lead to satisfying the desired formulae. Experiments in a variety of discrete and continuous domains demonstrate that our approach is able to zero-shot satisfy a wide range of finite- and infinite-horizon specifications, and outperforms existing methods in terms of both satisfaction probability and efficiency.

1 Introduction

One of the fundamental challenges in artificial intelligence (AI) is to create agents capable of following arbitrary instructions. While significant research efforts have been devoted to designing reinforcement learning (RL) agents that can complete tasks expressed in natural languageÂ (Oh etÂ al., 2017; Goyal etÂ al., 2019; Luketina etÂ al., 2019), recent years have witnessed increased interest in formal languages to specify tasks in RLÂ (Andreas etÂ al., 2017; Camacho etÂ al., 2019; Jothimurugan etÂ al., 2021). Formal specification languages offer several desirable properties over natural language, such as well-defined semantics and compositionality, allowing for the specification of unambiguous, structured tasksÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021; LeÃ³n etÂ al., 2022). Recent works have furthermore shown that it is possible to automatically translate many natural language instructions into a relevant specification language, providing interpretable yet precise representations of tasks, which is especially important in safety-critical domainsÂ (LeÃ³n etÂ al., 2021; Pan etÂ al., 2023; Liu etÂ al., 2023; Cohen etÂ al., 2024).

Linear temporal logic (LTL)Â (Pnueli, 1977) in particular has been adopted as a powerful formalism for instructing RL agentsÂ (Hasanbeig etÂ al., 2018; Araki etÂ al., 2021; Voloshin etÂ al., 2023). LTL is an appealing specification language that allows for the definition of tasks in terms of high-level features of the environment. These tasks can utilise complex compositional structure, are inherently temporally extended (i.e.Â non-Markovian), and naturally incorporate safety constraints.

While several approaches have been proposed to learning policies capable of satisfying arbitrary LTL specificationsÂ (Kuo etÂ al., 2020; Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021; Qiu etÂ al., 2023; Liu etÂ al., 2024), they suffer from several limitations. First, most existing methods are limited to subsets of LTL and cannot handle infinite-horizon (i.e.Â Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰-regular) specifications, which form an important class of objectives including persistence (eventually, a desired state needs to be reached forever), recurrence (a set of states needs to be reached infinitely often), and response (whenever a particular event happens, a task needs to be completed)Â (Manna & Pnueli, 1990). Second, many current techniques are myopic, that is, they solve tasks by independently completing individual subtasks, which can lead to inefficient, globally suboptimal solutionsÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021). Finally, existing approaches often do not adequately handle safety constraints of specifications, especially when tasks can be completed in multiple ways with different safety implications. For an illustration of these limitations, see FigureÂ 1.

In this paper, we develop a novel approach to learning policies for zero-shot execution of LTL specifications that addresses these shortcomings. Our method exploits the structure of BÃ¼chi automata to non-myopically reason about ways of completing a (possibly infinite-horizon) specification, and to ensure that safety constraints are satisfied. Our main contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    we develop (to the best of our knowledge) the first non-myopic approach to learning policies for zero-shot execution of LTL specifications that is applicable to infinite-horizon tasks;

  • â€¢

    we propose a novel representation of LTL formulae based on reach-avoid sequences of truth assignments, which allows us to learn policies that intrinsically consider safety constraints;

  • â€¢

    we propose a novel neural network architecture that combines DeepSets and RNNs to condition the policy on the desired specification;

  • â€¢

    lastly, we empirically validate the effectiveness of our method on a range of environments and tasks, demonstrating that it outperforms existing approaches in terms of satisfaction probability and efficiency.

Linear temporal logic.

Linear temporal logic (LTL)Â (Pnueli, 1977) provides a formalism to precisely specify properties of infinite trajectories. LTL formulae are defined over a set of atomic propositions Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P, which describe high-level features of the environment. The syntax of LTL formulae is recursively defined as

The semantics of LTL align with the intuitive meanings of its operators. BÃ¼chi automata.

A more practical way of reasoning about the semantics of LTL formulae is via BÃ¼chi automataÂ (BÃ¼chi, 1966), which are specialised automata that can be constructed to keep track of the progress towards satisfying a specification. 3 Problem setting

Our high-level goal is to find a specification-conditioned policy Ï€|Ï†conditionalğœ‹ğœ‘\pi|\varphiitalic_Ï€ | italic_Ï† that maximises the probability of satisfying arbitrary LTL formulae Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†. Formally, we introduce an arbitrary distribution Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ over LTL specifications Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†, and aim to compute the optimal policy

Proof.

The proof follows from (Voloshin etÂ al., 2023, Theorem 4.2) by repeated application of the linearity of expectation and triangle inequality. A detailed proof is given in SectionÂ B.2. âˆ

However, while the formulation in 1 provides desirable theoretical guarantees, it does not take into account any notion of efficiency of formula satisfaction, which is an important practical concern. Consider for example the simple formula ğ–¥â¢ğ–ºğ–¥ğ–º\mathsf{F}\,\mathsf{a}sansserif_F sansserif_a. Eventual discounting assigns the same return to all policies that eventually visit sğ‘ sitalic_s with ğ–ºâˆˆLâ¢(s)ğ–ºğ¿ğ‘ \mathsf{a}\in L(s)sansserif_a âˆˆ italic_L ( italic_s ), regardless of the number of steps required to materialise ğ–ºğ–º\mathsf{a}sansserif_a. In practice, we often prefer policies that are more efficient (require fewer steps to make progress towards satisfaction), even if their overall satisfaction probability might be slightly reduced. A natural way to formalise this tradeoff is as follows:

Problem 2 (Efficient LTL satisfaction).

Given an unknown MDP â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, a distribution over LTL formulae Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾, and LDBAs â„¬Ï†subscriptâ„¬ğœ‘\mathcal{B}_{\varphi}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each Ï†âˆˆsupp(Î¾)ğœ‘suppğœ‰\varphi\in\operatorname*{supp}(\xi)italic_Ï† âˆˆ roman_supp ( italic_Î¾ ), find the optimal policy

(2)

Here, we discount all time steps, such that more efficient policies receive higher returns. While solutions to 2 are not guaranteed to be probability-optimal (as per 1), they will generally still achieve a high probability of formula satisfaction, while also taking efficiency into account. We consider 2 for the rest of this paper, since we believe efficiency to be an important practical concern, but note that our approach is equally applicable to the eventual discounting setting (see SectionÂ B.3).

4 Method

Solving 2 requires us to train a policy conditioned on the current MDP state sğ‘ sitalic_s and the current state qğ‘qitalic_q of an LDBA constructed from a given target specification Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†. Our key insight is that we can extract a useful representation of qğ‘qitalic_q directly from the structure of the LDBA, by reasoning about the possible ways of satisfying the given formula from the current LDBA state qğ‘qitalic_q. This representation is then used to condition the policy, and guide the agent towards satisfying a given specification.

4.1 Representing LTL specifications as sequences

Computing accepting cycles.

An optimal policy for 2 must continuously visit accepting states in â„¬Ï†subscriptâ„¬ğœ‘\mathcal{B}_{\varphi}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since â„¬Ï†subscriptâ„¬ğœ‘\mathcal{B}_{\varphi}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is finite, this means that the agent has to reach an accepting cycle in the LDBA. Intuitively, the possible ways of reaching accepting cycles are an informative representation of the current LDBA state qğ‘qitalic_q, as they capture how to satisfy the given task. We compute all possible ways of reaching an accepting cycle using an algorithm based on depth-first search (DFS) that explores all possible paths from qğ‘qitalic_q to an accepting state qfâˆˆâ„±subscriptğ‘ğ‘“â„±q_{f}\in\mathcal{F}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_F, and then back to a state already contained in the path (see AppendixÂ C for details). Let Pqsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{q}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the resulting set of paths from qğ‘qitalic_q to accepting cycles.

Remark.

In the case that Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† corresponds to a task that can be completed in finite time (e.g.Â ğ–¥â¢ğ–ºğ–¥ğ–º\mathsf{F}\,\mathsf{a}sansserif_F sansserif_a), the accepting cycle in â„¬Ï†subscriptâ„¬ğœ‘\mathcal{B}_{\varphi}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is trivial and consists of only a single looping state (see e.g.Â q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in SectionÂ 2).

From paths to sequences.

4.2 Overview of the approach

Next, we describe the model architecture of the sequence-conditioned policy, and give a detailed description of the training procedure and test-time execution.

4.3 Model architecture

We parameterise the sequence-conditioned policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ using a modular neural network architecture. This consists of an observation module, which processes observations from the environment, a sequence module, which encodes the reach-avoid sequence, and an actor module, which takes as input the features produced by the previous two modules and outputs a distribution over actions.

The observation module is implemented as either a fully-connected (for generic state features) or convolutional neural network (for image-like observations). The actor module is another fully connected neural network that outputs the mean and standard deviation of a Gaussian distribution (for continuous action spaces) or the parameters of a categorical distribution (in the discrete setting). Finally, the sequence module consists of a permutation-invariant neural network that encodes sets of assignments, and a recurrent neural network (RNN) that maps the resulting sequence to a final representation. We discuss these components in further detail below and provide an illustration of the sequence module in FigureÂ 3.

Representing sets of assignments.

The first step of the sequence module consists in encoding the sets of assignments in a reach-avoid sequence. We employ the DeepSets architectureÂ (Zaheer etÂ al., 2017) to obtain an encoding ğ’†Asubscriptğ’†ğ´\bm{e}_{A}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a set of assignments Ağ´Aitalic_A. That is, we have

ğ’†A=Ïâ¢(âˆ‘aâˆˆAÏ•â¢(a)),subscriptğ’†ğ´ğœŒsubscriptğ‘ğ´italic-Ï•ğ‘\bm{e}_{A}=\rho\left(\sum_{a\in A}\phi(a)\right),bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( italic_a ) ) , (4)

where Ï•â¢(a)italic-Ï•ğ‘\phi(a)italic_Ï• ( italic_a ) is a learned embedding function, and ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is a learned non-linear transformation. Note that the resulting encoding ğ’†Asubscriptğ’†ğ´\bm{e}_{A}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is permutation-invariant, i.e.Â it does not depend on the order in which the elements in Ağ´Aitalic_A are processed, and EquationÂ 4 is thus a well-defined function on sets.

Representing reach-avoid sequences.

Once we have obtained encodings of the sets Ai+superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}^{+}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Aiâˆ’superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}^{-}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each element in the reach-avoid sequence Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, we concatenate these embeddings and pass them through an RNN to yield the final representation of the sequence. Since Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is an infinite sequence, we approximate it with a finite prefix by repeating its looping part kğ‘˜kitalic_k times, such that the truncated sequence visits an accepting state exactly kğ‘˜kitalic_k times. We apply the RNN backwards, that is, from the end of the truncated sequence to the beginning, since earlier elements in Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ are more important for the immediate actions of the policy. The particular model of RNN we employ is a gated recurrent unit (GRU)Â (Cho etÂ al., 2014).

4.4 Training procedure

We train the policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and the value function VÏ€superscriptğ‘‰ğœ‹V^{\pi}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using the general framework of goal-conditioned RLÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022). That is, we generate a random reach-avoid sequence at the beginning of each training episode and reward the agent for successfully completing it. In particular, given a training sequence Ïƒ=((A1+,A1âˆ’),â€¦,(An+,Anâˆ’))ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ´1superscriptsubscriptğ´1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘›\sigma=\left((A_{1}^{+},A_{1}^{-}),\ldots,(A_{n}^{+},A_{n}^{-})\right)italic_Ïƒ = ( ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ), we keep track of the task satisfaction progress via an index iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] (where initially i=1ğ‘–1i=1italic_i = 1). In our experiments, we use proximal policy optimisation (PPO)Â (Schulman etÂ al., 2017) to optimise the policy, but our approach can be combined with any RL algorithm.

Curriculum learning.

To improve the training of Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ in practice, we employ a simple form of curriculum learningÂ (Narvekar etÂ al., 2020) in order to gradually expose the policy to more challenging tasks. A curriculum consists of multiple stages that correspond to training sequences of increasing length and complexity. For example, the first stage generally consists only of simple reach-tasks of the form Ïƒ=(({{p}},âˆ…))ğœğ‘\sigma=\bigl{(}(\{\{p\}\},\emptyset)\bigr{)}italic_Ïƒ = ( ( { { italic_p } } , âˆ… ) ) for pâˆˆAâ¢Pğ‘ğ´ğ‘ƒp\in APitalic_p âˆˆ italic_A italic_P, while later stages involve longer sequences with avoidance conditions. Once the policy achieves satisfactory performance on the current tasks, we move on to the next stage. For details on the exact curricula we use in our experiments, see TableÂ 5.

Strict negative assignments.

Recall that a negative assignment in a reach-avoid sequence Ïƒpsubscriptğœğ‘\sigma_{p}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is any assignment that leads to an LDBA state other than the desired next state in pğ‘pitalic_p. In practice, we find that trying to avoid all other states in the LDBA can be too restrictive for the policy. We now discuss how to handle Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-transitions in the LDBA. If the sequence Ïƒâˆ—superscriptğœ\sigma^{*}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT chosen at qğ‘qitalic_q starts with an Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-transition (i.e.Â A1+={Îµ}superscriptsubscriptğ´1ğœ€A_{1}^{+}=\{\varepsilon\}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_Îµ }), we extend the action space of Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ to include the action Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ. In the continuous case, we learn the probability pğ‘pitalic_p of taking the Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-action and model Ï€(â‹…|s,Ïƒâˆ—)\pi(\cdot|s,\sigma^{*})italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_s , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) as a mixed continuous/discrete probability distribution (see e.g.Â (Shynk, 2012, Ch.Â 3.6)). Whenever the policy executes the Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-action, we update the current LDBA state to the next state in the selected path. In practice, we additionally only allow Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-actions if Lâ¢(s)âˆ‰A2âˆ’ğ¿ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ´2L(s)\not\in A_{2}^{-}italic_L ( italic_s ) âˆ‰ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since in that case taking the Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-transition would immediately lead to failure.

4.6 Discussion

We argue that our approach has several advantages over existing methods. Since we operate on accepting cycles of BÃ¼chi automata, our method is applicable to infinite-horizon (i.e.Â Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰-regular) tasks, contrary to most existing approaches. Our method is the first approach that is also non-myopic, as it is able to reason about the entire structure of a specification via temporally extended reach-avoid sequences. This reasoning naturally considers safety constraints, which are represented through negative assignments and inform the policy about which propositions to avoid. Crucially, these safety constraints are considered during planning, i.e.Â when selecting the optimal sequence to execute, rather than only during execution. For a detailed comparison of our approach to related work, see SectionÂ 6.

5 Experiments

We evaluate our approach, called DeepLTL, in a variety of environments and on a range of LTL specifications of varying difficulty. We aim to answer the following questions: (1) Is DeepLTL able to learn policies that can zero-shot satisfy complex LTL specifications? (2) How does our method compare to relevant baselines in terms of both satisfaction probability and efficiency? (3) Can our approach successfully handle infinite-horizon specifications?

5.1 Experimental setup

Environments.

Our experiments involve different domains with varying state and action spaces. This includes the LetterWorld environmentÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021), a 7Ã—7777\times 77 Ã— 7 discrete grid world in which letters corresponding to atomic propositions occupy randomly sampled positions in the grid. We also consider the high-dimensional ZoneEnv environment from Vaezipoor etÂ al. (2021), in which a robotic agent with a continuous action space has to navigate between different randomly placed coloured regions, which correspond to the atomic propositions. Finally, we evaluate our approach on the continuous FlatWorld environmentÂ (Voloshin etÂ al., 2023), in which multiple propositions can hold true at the same time. We provide further details and visualisations in SectionÂ D.1.

LTL specifications.

We consider a range of tasks of varying complexity. The specifications we consider cover a wide range of LTL objectives, including reachability, safety, recurrence, persistence, and combinations thereof. Details on the exact specifications we use in each environment are given in SectionÂ D.2.

Baselines.

We compare DeepLTL to two state-of-the-art approaches for learning general LTL-satisfying policies. LTL2ActionÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021) encodes the syntax tree of a target formula via a graph neural network (GNN) and uses a procedure known as LTL progression to progress through the specification based on the observed propositions. The second baseline, GCRL-LTLÂ (Qiu etÂ al., 2023), instead learns proposition-conditioned policies and combines them compositionally using a weighted graph search on the BÃ¼chi automaton of a target specification.

Evaluation protocol.

In line with previous work, the methods are trained for 15M interaction steps on each environment with PPOÂ (Schulman etÂ al., 2017). Details about hyperparameters and neural network architectures can be found in SectionÂ D.3. We report the performance in terms of discounted return over the number of environment interactions (following EquationÂ 2) on randomly sampled reach/avoid tasks, and provide tabular results detailing the success rate (SR) and average number of steps until completion (Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼) of trained policies on complex tasks. All results are averaged across 5 different random seeds. Furthermore, we provide visualisations of trajectories of trained policies for various specifications in the ZoneEnv and FlatWorld environments in SectionÂ E.5.

5.2 Results

Finite-horizon tasks.

FigureÂ 4 shows the discounted return achieved on reach/avoid tasks across environment interactions. DeepLTL clearly outperforms the baselines, both in terms of sample efficiency and final performance. The results in TableÂ 1 further demonstrate that our method can efficiently zero-shot satisfy complex specifications (see SectionÂ D.2 for details on the tasks), achieving higher success rates (SR) than existing approaches, while requiring significantly fewer steps (Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼). These results highlight the performance benefits of our representation based on reach-avoid sequences over existing encoding schemes, and show that our approach learns much more efficient policies than the myopic baseline GCRL-LTL. The higher success rates of our method furthermore indicate that it handles safety constraints better than the baselines.

Infinite-horizon tasks.

FigureÂ 6 shows example trajectories of DeepLTL on infinite-horizon tasks in the ZoneEnv environment. Further experimental results.

We provide further experimental results in AppendixÂ E, investigating safety requirements, generalisation to longer sequences, and the impact of curriculum learning.

6 Related work

RL with tasks expressed in LTL has received significant attention in the last few yearsÂ (Sadigh etÂ al., 2014; DeÂ Giacomo etÂ al., 2018; Camacho etÂ al., 2019). Our approach builds on previous works that use LDBAs to augment the state space of the MDPÂ (Hasanbeig etÂ al., 2018; Cai etÂ al., 2021; Voloshin etÂ al., 2022; Hasanbeig etÂ al., 2023; Bagatella etÂ al., 2024; Shah etÂ al., 2024). However, these methods are limited to finding policies for a single specification and cannot deal with multiple different tasks.

Among the works that consider multiple, previously unseen specifications, many approaches decompose a given task into subtasks, which are then individually completedÂ (Araki etÂ al., 2021; LeÃ³n etÂ al., 2021; 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2024). However, as noted by Vaezipoor etÂ al. (2021) this results in myopic behaviour and hence potentially suboptimal solutions. In contrast, our approach takes the entire specification into account by reasoning over temporally extended reach-avoid sequences. Kuo etÂ al. (2020) instead propose to compose RNNs in a way that mirrors formula structure, which however requires learning a non-stationary policy. This is addressed by LTL2ActionÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021), which encodes the syntax tree of a target specification using a GNN and uses LTL progressionÂ (Bacchus & Kabanza, 2000) to make the problem Markovian. We instead extract reach-avoid sequences from BÃ¼chi automata, which directly encode the possible ways of satisfying the given specification. Furthermore, due to its reliance on LTL progression, LTL2Action is restricted to the finite-horizon fragment of LTL, whereas our approach is able to handle infinite-horizon tasks.

The only previous method we are aware of that can deal with infinite-horizon specifications is GCRL-LTLÂ (Qiu etÂ al., 2023). However, similar to other approaches, GCRL-LTL relies on composing policies for sub-tasks and therefore produces suboptimal behaviour. Furthermore, the approach only considers safety constraints during task execution and not during high-level planning. Recently, Xu & Fekri (2024) proposed future dependent options for satisfying arbitrary LTL tasks, which are option policies that depend on propositions to be achieved in the future. While sharing some similarities with our approach, their method is only applicable to a fragment of LTL that does not support conjunction nor infinite-horizon specifications, and does not consider safety constraints during planning.

7 Conclusion

We have introduced DeepLTL, a novel approach to the problem of learning policies that can zero-shot execute arbitrary LTL specifications. Our method represents a given specification as a set of reach-avoid sequences of truth assignments, and exploits a general sequence-conditioned policy to execute arbitrary LTL instructions at test time. In contrast to existing techniques, our method can handle infinite-horizon specifications, is non-myopic, and naturally considers safety constraints. Through extensive experiments, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of our approach in practice.

In future work, we plan on improving sample efficiency by incorporating ideas such as counterfactual experienceÂ (ToroÂ Icarte etÂ al., 2022; Voloshin etÂ al., 2023) and automated reward shapingÂ (Bagatella etÂ al., 2024; Shah etÂ al., 2024). We also plan on investigating more involved neural network architectures, e.g.Â based on attention, along the lines of LeÃ³n etÂ al. (2022).

Appendix B Learning probability-optimal policies

B.1 Eventual discounting

To see why eventual discounting is necessary, we first examine the problem of finding an optimal policy for a single LTL specification Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†. Consider the product MDP â„³Ï†superscriptâ„³ğœ‘\mathcal{M}^{\varphi}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT depicted in FigureÂ 7, adapted from Voloshin etÂ al. (2023). The policy starts in state s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and can choose either action ağ‘aitalic_a or action bğ‘bitalic_b. Action ağ‘aitalic_a always leads to an infinite cycle containing an accepting state, and is thus optimal. Action bğ‘bitalic_b on the other hand also leads to an infinite cycle with probability 0.990.990.990.99, but may lead to a sink state with probability 0.010.010.010.01.

Let Ï€asubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{a}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the policy that chooses ağ‘aitalic_a and Ï€bsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{b}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the policy that chooses bğ‘bitalic_b. Without eventual discounting, we have:

Jâ¢(Ï€a)=11âˆ’Î³2andJâ¢(Ï€b)=0.991âˆ’Î³,formulae-sequenceğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘11superscriptğ›¾2andğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘0.991ğ›¾J(\pi_{a})=\frac{1}{1-\gamma^{2}}\qquad\text{and}\qquad J(\pi_{b})=\frac{0.99}% {1-\gamma},italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG and italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 0.99 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG ,

and thus Jâ¢(Ï€b)>Jâ¢(Ï€a)ğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘J(\pi_{b})>J(\pi_{a})italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for all Î³âˆˆ(0.01,1)ğ›¾0.011\gamma\in(0.01,1)italic_Î³ âˆˆ ( 0.01 , 1 ). Hence, maximising (standard) expected discounted return produces a suboptimal policy in terms of satisfaction probability.

Eventual discounting addresses this problem by only discounting visits to accepting states, and not the steps in between. In the previous example, this means that Jâ¢(Ï€a)>Jâ¢(Ï€b)ğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ½subscriptğœ‹ğ‘J(\pi_{a})>J(\pi_{b})italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_J ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), in line with the satisfaction probability. See Voloshin etÂ al. (2023) for a formal derivation of a bound on the performance of the return-optimal policy under eventual discounting. We next extend this result to the setting of a distribution Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ over LTL specifications Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†.

B.3 DeepLTL with eventual discounting

DeepLTL can be readily extended with eventual discounting for settings in which satisfaction probability is the primary concern, and efficiency is less important. In this case, we want to use our approach to approximate a solution to 1.

To do so, we only need to assume access to the distribution Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ over LTL formulae. During training, we sample specifications Ï†âˆ¼Î¾similar-toğœ‘ğœ‰\varphi\sim\xiitalic_Ï† âˆ¼ italic_Î¾ and train the sequence-conditioned policy using all reach-avoid sequences extracted from â„¬Ï†subscriptâ„¬ğœ‘\mathcal{B}_{\varphi}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Crucially, we extend each step of a reach-avoid sequence to include an additional boolean flag that specifies whether the corresponding LDBA transition leads to an accepting state. These flags are given as input to the policy network, and are used to compute the eventual discounting objective. The rest of our approach remains unchanged. We leave an experimental investigation of this scheme for future work.

Appendix C Computing accepting cycles

The algorithm to compute paths to accepting cycles is listed in AlgorithmÂ 1.

Appendix D Experimental details

D.1 Environments

LetterWorld.

The LetterWorld environment has been introduced by Vaezipoor etÂ al. (2021). It is a 7Ã—7777\times 77 Ã— 7 grid world that contains 12 randomly placed letters corresponding to atomic propositions. Each letter appears twice, i.e.Â 24 out of the 49 squares are occupied, and there are thus multiple ways of solving any given task. The agent observes the full grid from an egocentric view. At each step, the agent can move up, right, down, or left. If it moves out of bounds, the agent is immediately placed on the opposite end of the grid. See FigureÂ 8(a) for an illustration of the LetterWorld environment.

ZoneEnv.

We adapt the ZoneEnv environment introduced by Vaezipoor etÂ al. (2021). The environment is a walled plane with 8 circular regions (â€œzonesâ€) that have four different colours and form the atomic propositions. Our implementation is based on the Safety Gymnasium suiteÂ (Ji etÂ al., 2023) and uses the Point robot, which has a continuous action space for acceleration and steering. The environment features a high-dimensional state space based on lidar information about the zones, and data from other sensors. Both the zone and robot positions are randomly sampled at the beginning of each episode. If the agent at any point touches a wall, it receives a penalty and the episode is immediately terminated. A visualisation of the ZoneEnv environment is provided in FigureÂ 8(b).

FlatWorld.

The FlatWorld environmentÂ (Voloshin etÂ al., 2023; Shah etÂ al., 2024) consists of a two-dimensional continuous world (ğ’®=â„2ğ’®superscriptâ„2\mathcal{S}=\mathbb{R}^{2}caligraphic_S = blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) with a discrete action space. Atomic propositions are given by various coloured regions. Importantly, these regions overlap in various places, which means that multiple propositions can hold true at the same time. The initial agent position is sampled randomly from the space in which no propositions are true. At each time step, the agent can move in one of the 8 compass directions. If it leaves the boundary of the world, the agent receives a penalty and the episode is terminated prematurely. FigureÂ 8(c) shows a visualisation of the FlatWorld environment.

D.2 Testing specifications

TablesÂ 2 andÂ 3 list the finite and infinite-horizon specifications used in our evaluation, respectively.

D.3 Hyperparameters

Neural network architectures.

Our choice of neural network architectures is similar to previous workÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021). For DeepLTL and LTL2Action, we employ a fully connected actor network with [64, 64, 64] units and ReLU as the activation function. The critic has network structure [64, 64] and uses Tanh activations in LetterWorld and ZoneEnv, and ReLU activations in FlatWorld. The actor is composed with a softmax layer in discrete action spaces, and outputs the mean and standard deviation of a Gaussian distribution in continuous action spaces. GCRL-LTL uses somewhat larger actor and critic networks with structure [512, 1024, 256] and ReLU activations in the ZoneEnv environment.

The observation module is environment-specific. For the ZoneEnv and FlatWorld environments, it consists of a simple fully connected network with [128, 64] units and Tanh activations, or [16, 16] units and ReLU activations, respectively. GCRL-LTL instead uses a simple projection of the input to dimensionality 100 in ZoneEnv. For LetterWorld, the observation module is a CNN with 16, 32, and 64 channels in three hidden layers, a kernel size of 2Ã—2222\times 22 Ã— 2, stride of 1, no padding, and ReLU activations.

Finally, the sequence module consists of learned embeddings Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• of dimensionality 32 in LetterWorld, and 16 in ZoneEnv and FlatWorld. The non-linear transformation ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is a fully connected network with [32, 32] units in LetterWorld, and [32, 16] units in ZoneEnv and FlatWorld. We use ReLU activations throughout for the sequence module. For the baselines, we use the hyperparameters reported in the respective papersÂ (Vaezipoor etÂ al., 2021; Qiu etÂ al., 2023).

PPO hyperparameters.

The hyperparameters for PPOÂ (Schulman etÂ al., 2017) are listed in TableÂ 4. We use the Adam optimiserÂ (Kingma & Ba, 2015) for all methods and environments.

Additional hyperparameters.

LTL2Action requires an LTL task sampler to sample a random training specification at the beginning of each episode. We follow Vaezipoor etÂ al. (2021) and sample specifications from the space of reach/avoid tasks. We also experimented with sampling more complex specifications, but found this detrimental to performance. For GCRL-LTL, we set the value threshold Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ to 0.9 in the ZoneEnv environment, and 0.92 in LetterWorld and FlatWorld. The threshold Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» for strict negative assignments in DeepLTL is set to 0.4 across experiments.

D.4 Training curricula

We design training curricula in order to gradually expose the policy to more challenging tasks. The general structure of the curricula is the same across environments: we start with simple and short reach-avoid sequences, and move to more complicated sequences once the policy achieves satisfactory performance.

LetterWorld.

In the LetterWorld environment, the first curriculum stage consists of reach-avoid tasks of depth 1 with single propositions, e.g. ({{a}},{{b}}})\left(\{\{a\}\},\{\{b\}\}\}\right)( { { italic_a } } , { { italic_b } } } ). Once the policy achieves an average satisfaction rate of 95%percent9595\%95 % on these sequences, we move to the next curriculum stage, in which the depth is still 1, and |A1+|â‰¤2,|A1âˆ’|â‰¤2formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ´12superscriptsubscriptğ´12|A_{1}^{+}|\leq 2,|A_{1}^{-}|\leq 2| italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‰¤ 2 , | italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‰¤ 2. The next stage consists of the same tasks with a length of 2. ZoneEnv.

FlatWorld.

In FlatWorld, we first sample a mixture of reach- and reach-avoid sequences of depth up to 2. Once the policy achieves a success rate of 80%percent8080\%80 %, we increase the cardinality of the positive and negative assignments up to 2.

E.1 Results on persistence tasks

Persistence (a.k.a.Â reach-stay) tasks of the form ğ–¥â¢ğ–¦â¢ğ–ºğ–¥ğ–¦ğ–º\mathsf{F}\,\mathsf{G}\,\mathsf{a}sansserif_F sansserif_G sansserif_a specify that a proposition needs to be true forever from some point on. E.2 Adversarial tasks with safety constraints

We next demonstrate the advantages of our approach in terms of handling safety constraints on an adversarial task. This task is specifically designed to require considering safety requirements during high-level planning. We consider the configuration of the ZoneEnv environment depicted in FigureÂ 9 and the specification Ï†=Â¬ğ–»ğ—…ğ—ğ–¾â¢ğ–´â¢(ğ—€ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ–¾ğ—‡âˆ¨ğ—’ğ–¾ğ—…ğ—…ğ—ˆğ—)âˆ§ğ–¥â¢ğ—†ğ–ºğ—€ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—ğ–ºğœ‘ğ–»ğ—…ğ—ğ–¾ğ–´ğ—€ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—’ğ–¾ğ—…ğ—…ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¥ğ—†ğ–ºğ—€ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—ğ–º\varphi=\neg\mathsf{blue}\;\mathsf{U}\;(\mathsf{green}\lor\mathsf{yellow})% \land\mathsf{F}\,\mathsf{magenta}italic_Ï† = Â¬ sansserif_blue sansserif_U ( sansserif_green âˆ¨ sansserif_yellow ) âˆ§ sansserif_F sansserif_magenta.

FigureÂ 9 shows a number of sample trajectories generated by DeepLTL (top row) and GCRL-LTL (bottom row). Evidently, GCRL-LTL fails at satisfying the task, since it decides on reaching the green region during high-level planning without considering the safety constraint Â¬ğ–»ğ—…ğ—ğ–¾ğ–»ğ—…ğ—ğ–¾\neg\mathsf{blue}Â¬ sansserif_blue. In contrast, DeepLTL considers this safety requirement when selecting the optimal reach-avoid sequence, and hence chooses to reach the yellow region instead.

Quantitatively, GCRL-LTL only succeeds in satisfying the task in 9.2%percent9.29.2\%9.2 % of cases, whereas DeepLTL achieves a success rate of 79.6%percent79.679.6\%79.6 % (averaged over 5 seeds and 100 episodes per seed). While LTL2Action does not have a high-level planning component, it considers the entire task including safety constraints via its GNN encoding, and averages a success rate of 50.2%percent50.250.2\%50.2 %.

E.3 Generalisation to longer sequences

In this section, we investigate the ability of our approach to generalise to longer sequences. Our evaluation so far has already demonstrated that our method can successfully learn general behaviour for satisfying LTL specifications by only training on simple reach-avoid sequences. We observe that our approach generalises well to longer sequences and outperforms the baselines in terms of satisfaction probability and efficiency.

E.4 Ablation study

We conduct an ablation study in the LetterWorld environment to investigate the impact of curriculum learning. We train our method without any training curriculum by directly sampling random reach-avoid sequences of length 3, with potentially multiple propositions to reach and avoid at each stage. Evaluation curves on reach/avoid specifications over training are shown in FigureÂ 10. The results demonstrate that curriculum training improves sample efficiency and reduces variance across seeds.
